questions.question_text:
The project team is working on the requirements specifications for a new product. The team reached a decision on which requirements will be included in the next release. A third of the stakeholders endorse one approach while no other approach achieved more than a quarter of the vote.
Which decision role was used?

A company’s management team has decided to deploy a new product. However, there is concern that users may not accept a new product that forces them to change existing practices.
The business analyst should:

choices.C: delay the application’s deployment until the conflicts have been resolved.
choices.A: adhere to the project plan to achieve project objectives.
choices.B: clearly communicate project objectives and attempt to defuse tensions.
choices.D: voice user concerns to management and recommend that the project be closed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The best option to determine the scope of the change on the product would be the requirements traceability matrix (option B).

A requirements traceability matrix is a tool used to trace the relationships between the different requirements of a product, such as functional requirements, design requirements, and test cases. It helps to ensure that all requirements are properly traced and linked to the relevant design, implementation, and testing activities. This can be useful in determining the scope of a change to an existing feature, as it can help to identify which requirements are impacted by the change and what work needs to be done to implement it.

A business analyst is assigned to a business process re-engineering project. In addition to planning a workshop to elicit requirements, the business analyst wants to send out a survey to gather data to use in a statistical analysis on user satisfaction with the current business process.
Which of the following types of surveys would be most appropriate to create and why?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The Likert scale is a standard classification format for studies. The respondents provide their opinion (data) about the quality of a product/service from high to low or better to worse using two, four, five, or seven levels.
It's a great way to identify ambiguous or unverifiable requirements by having the whole team review them together.
